text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Baked Alaska that's right
don't believe everything you hear in the
lamestream media about this gorgeous
desert being hard to make it's not it's
super easy and is it so simple that a
certain former governor of Alaska could
make it oh you betcha
so despite its fancy looks this is
really super basic and requires almost
no cooking okay so let's get started and
first up we have to mold some ice cream
and I'm just gonna use a couple soup
cups but this technique is literally
going to work with any shape or size
container and one tip put these in the
freezer for about a half-hour before you
make this and that will help prevent the
ice cream from melting while we're
working with it during this step and
then what we'll do is we'll line the
mold with some plastic and begin
scooping in some ice cream so first up
I'm going to put in a couple scoops of
raspberry ice cream and we want to make
sure we're pressing down firmly and once
whatever we're using for our first
flavor of ice cream is in we'll take our
scoop and make a nice well in the middle
into which we will put our second ice
cream in my case some french vanilla and
obviously you can use any ice cream
flavors you want here you could just do
one flavor you could do three flavors
but using more than one flavor
definitely makes for a more impressive
presentation and then once that's been
done we can move on to the last
component of the inside of this at least
which would be the cake layer and for
this I'm just using some high-quality
store-bought chocolate sponge cake and
unless you have a lot of free time in
your hands
don't make homemade cake for this you
bake a homemade cake when you want to
eat homemade cake not when you want to
eat Baked Alaska so I'm using
store-bought and all we need to do is
cut a thick slice and then we'll cut or
stamp out a round piece that will fit
our cup and as you can see my cake
wasn't quite wide enough but that's
really not going to matter because we're
going to cover everything with our
Italian meringue and once we've cut our
cake to fit we'll press that down firmly
on top of our ice cream as you can see
I'm pressing down and want to make sure
everything's nice and compact in there
and we'll wrap those up and at this
point we're going to transfer those into
the freezer until they are frozen solid
alright at least a few hours overnight
is even better all right so really the
only way to screw this up is to not
freeze that stuff solid enough before
you do the meringue so you're gonna have
to decide how long to leave that in the
freezer
you're the sarah palin of not fallon so
make sure it's frozen solid but once it
is we can move on to the last step which
is our
Italian meringue so in the bowl of my
stand mixer I have two egg whites to
which we're going to add a squeeze of
lemon juice the acid in the juice is
going to help stabilize these whites and
what we'll do is we use the whisk
attachment on our mixer and we will beat
these egg whites to the soft peak stage
at which point we will introduce our
sugar so I want you to stop right at
this point all right we don't have stiff
peaks we have very soft very fuzzy very
floppy peaks and at this point if we
were making just a regular meringue we
would just sprinkle in the sugar and
beat it some more but for an Italian
meringue we're actually going to add a
very hot sugar syrup so into a little
saucepan we're going to add some
granulated sugar and a splash of water
and we will bring that over to the stove
and put it on medium high heat and of
course that sugar is going to dissolve
and it's going to start to simmer and
what we need to do is cook this -
exactly 240 degrees Fahrenheit please do
not accidentally cook this to 240
degrees Celsius that's going to be a
little too far all right so make sure
you have a candy thermometer or one of
these probe thermometers a lot of people
like to leave the heat on medium high
too high for this I don't once mine
starts boiling I like to back the heat
down to medium or even medium low so
this goes kind of slow because it can
shoot right past that target temperature
super quick oh and one other thing you
see those grains of sugar stuck to the
sides of the pot you're actually
supposed to take a wet paint brush and
kind of brush those down back into the
mixture but I don't I can't be bothered
and you know what it's never caused a
problem but anyway like I said we're
going to cook this to 240 degrees at
which point we're going to remove it
from the stove will turn our mixer back
on and while it's whipping we will
carefully and slowly pour that sugar
syrup in in a thin but steady stream so
if you look straight across to the back
of the bowl you can see that being
poured in and I try to aim for right
where the meringue meets the bowl okay
right on that edge and because that
stuff is so hot it's going to actually
cook those egg whites which creates a
very stable very easy to work with
meringue and don't be alarmed but you
will actually notice steam coming out of
the bowl totally normal and if you feel
the side with your hand it's going to be
very hot and all we need to do here is
continue mixing on high speed until the
mixture cools down and we have some very
very stiff peaks and I mean stiff so I'm
filling the bowl here and it's gone from
very hot to just barely warm so I'm
going to turn that off and take a look
and this is exactly what you want
very beautiful very creamy but very very
stiff peaks so that's perfect look at
that now that's a stiff peak you could
put an eye out with that and assuming
our ice cream and cake molds are now
completely frozen we can move on to
final production
so we'll unwrap our ice cream we will
invert that on a plate and we will cover
it in some decorative fashion with our
meringue and I decided to do two for you
so this first one will be a little
fancier so I'm going to pipe around the
bottom and then we'll pipe straight up
from the bottom to the top and as you
can see because we're using that Italian
meringue this stuff is really going to
hold those sharp lines which as you'll
see it's kind of a big deal when we
Brown this and once you've completed
that you can just leave the top rough
like that but since this was the fancy
one I decided to take a little off the
top
flatten it out a little bit so I could
pipe some really nice rosettes on the
top alright so that was fancy design
number one and then for the second one
if you want you can go a lot simpler and
just cover it all over with little
rosettes which while not as intricate
still looks amazing
in fact the takeaway here is not to
worry too much about your design once
this is brown no matter what you've done
is going to look amazing okay and once
we've covered that with whatever design
we're doing the last step is to brown
the outside and probably the easiest way
is a blowtorch although I'm the blogger
will give you instructions to use a hot
oven instead and you want to use a light
touch here all right we really just want
to brown the ridges so we have that
beautiful contrast between the dark
brown and that bright white underneath
so we will go around we'll brown that
meringue and once you're happy with how
it looks which for me was right here
your Baked Alaska is done and ready to
eat I mean come on how gorgeous is that
and we hardly did any work so let's go
ahead and cut into this so we can see
what we have and as beautiful as the
outside was the insides every bit is
pretty and you can see here why you want
to use more than one flavor of ice cream
I think those multiple layers really add
to this and then traditionally at this
point I would just start eating but I
want to show you one amazing trick /
discovery if you don't have a blowtorch
and don't want to heat your oven up to
500 just to use it for a couple minutes
you can actually use a windproof lighter
to do this oh yeah there's no camera
tricks here I browned this entire Baked
Alaska using a cheap windproof lighter
in fact if we're being honest this
actually did a better job and was easier
to control than the blowtorch so there
you go very cheap very cool alternative
so I browned up my fancy one and then
speaking of fancy if you want you can
always serve this flambe style this was
just a little bit of brandy that I
warmed up ignited and spooned over and
had I thought to close the blinds that
would have looked incredible and besides
the flames that liquor is actually going
to soak into the cake as it sits on the
plate so it's your classic win-win but
anyway let me cut into this one so
actually can take the official bite or
two and it should come as a shock to no
one the cake ice cream and Italian
meringue are really good together and
obviously any combination of cake or ice
cream flavors will work
sky's the limit up to you so you really
can tailor this to your tastes so
whether you're making this for some
special occasion like Valentine's Day or
or you just want an easy make-ahead
dessert for a weeknight dinner I really
do hope you give this Baked Alaska
technique a try soon okay so head over
to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
